awd_titl_txt: Minimal Surfaces in Geometric Variational Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Differential geometry is a modern version of Euclidean geometry that studies shapes inside curved surfaces in any number of dimensions. Two key notions in differential geometry, besides "length" and "angle," are: "minimal surfaces," which generalize the concept of a straight line, and "curvature," which measures how a surface is bent. The early development of differential geometry is partly attributable to physics. In the early 20th century, Einstein formulated a geometric theory of gravitation, general relativity, asserting that we live in a curved four-dimensional world ("spacetime") where energy and mass are manifestations of the curvature of spacetime, and minimal surfaces are indicative of black hole boundaries. Nowadays, differential geometry and minimal surfaces are at the heart of several physical theories and active mathematical research directions. The principal investigator (PI) will study problems regarding minimal surfaces that are motivated by general relativity and by the van der Walls--Cahn--Hilliard theory of phase transitions for multicomponent alloy systems. This project will also support the proposer's efforts to promote student learning, inclusion, and training through summer schools, workshops, and conferences, as well as via expository articles and notes.

This project spans three related active research areas of minimal surface theory in differential geometry. First, the PI will investigate the construction of minimal surfaces as limiting min-max phase transitions. This construction has been recently shown to exhibit certain desirable stability properties that led to the proof of the "multiplicity one min-max conjecture" in three dimensions by the PI and Chodosh. The PI will continue this program, to produce surfaces with different curvatures and in different dimensions, as well as to better understand geometric implications of stable phase transitions. Second, as a step toward understanding limits of manifolds with nonnegative scalar curvature, the PI will study smooth and non-smooth three- and four-dimensional manifolds with nonnegative scalar curvature via the inherent bending effects of their embedded minimal surfaces. Third, the PI will apply this study of bending effects of minimal surfaces to investigate conjectured relationships between different mass notions in general relativity, where time-symmetric initial data sets are precisely manifolds with nonnegative scalar curvature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the period funded by this grant the PI and his coauthors have achieved significant results in the investigation of minimal surfaces in geometric variational problems. Variational problems generally involve the minimization or maximization of natural quantities, so minimal surfaces enter in abundance in geometric such problems as they are the suitable generalization of the concept of a straight line. The PI specifically studied minimal surfaces in three particular contexts: area minimization and gradient descent such as in the setting of soap bubble formation; the van der Walls--Cahn--Hilliard theory of phase transitions for multicomponent alloy systems; and, general relativity.

In the context of area minimization and gradient descent, the PI's work focused primarily on area minimizing hypersurfaces, the mean curvature flow, and singularity formation. With Choi, the PI established a flexible classification tool for so-called ancient gradient flows, which are singularity models for gradient flows. Then, with Choi, Chodosh, and Schulze the PI invoked this tool to study  generic singularity formation phenomena for mean curvature flows in three-dimensional space. Finally, with Choi, Chodosh, and Schulze, and then with Chodosh and Schulze the PI made further progress toward the understanding of generic singularity formation phenomena in higher dimensional spaces with low entropy conditions. In two different works, the PI together with Chodosh and Schulze used similar insights to show singularity formation in the area minimization problem can be generically avoided in dimensions up to 10.

In the context of the van der Walls--Cahn--Hilliard theory of phase transitions, the PI showed that double well phase transitions on surfaces that are obtained by mountain pass constructions or more generally have Morse index at most one can be used to construct geodesics with at most one point of self-intersection. With Chodosh, the PI studied double well phase transitions obtained from an integrable potential via min-max constructions and they showed that on surfaces they give rise to geodesics with a controlled number of self-intersections. Again with Chodosh, the PI also proved a strong multiplicity-one theorem for double well phase transitions in three-dimensional manifolds that arise from min-max constructions, and in separate work, they showed that min-max constructions give rise to minimal hypersurfaces with arbitrarily large area. The PI also began a study of the stronger rigidity properties of double well phase transition versus underlying minimal hypersurfaces, as well as variational properties of double well phase transitions with a Lagrangian term.

In the context of general relativity, the PI's work has focused on the Riemannian initial data sets for the Lorentzian problem, in which setting, energy density is described by the scalar curvature of the manifold and the mean curvature of a hypersurface helps detect whether the surface is inside or outside the black hole boundary. With Miao and Tam, the PI studied quasi-local mass properties of surfaces outside of black hole boundaries. With Li, the PI proved that the mass of a four-dimensional initial data set is not sensitive to the intrinsic shape of its black hole boundaries. Using tools from this work, with Bamler and Li the PI deduced new decompositions of four-dimensional manifolds with positive scalar curvature.

During the funded period the PI has co-organized numerous seminars and has given many talks sharing his research results in seminars, workshops and conferences. He has taught courses and mentored undergraduate and graduate students in topics related to the project through independent reading courses and learning groups. Finally, the PI has written expository articles on aspects of the project, all disseminated on his website.
